description:
Ancient boardgame from India meaning "The game of five". The goal of the game is to collect 3 pieces in a treasure island. The game play is simple: the player throws the 6 special dice and put his pieces in the path. Captures are possible too, and the winner is the player that moves all 3 pieces to his island.

A Sri Lankan race game for two players. It has elements of Ludo-type games, in as much that you both start with three men and you win by getting all three 'home'. The board is unusual, in that it is not a 'circle', rather it is a track of 31 spaces, with some spaces marked as castles and you are safe from being sent home on them.

1865 Sardinia is a board game belonging to the 18xx series for 2-4 players and set on the Sardinia island (and Corsica).

Players play the role of 19th century entrepreneurs investing in the construction as well as the financial and operational management of railways. Selling and buying shares on the stock market, seeking new sources of funding, laying track and placing stations, running trains and paying dividends are all basic elements of 18xx games.

In addition, 1865 Sardinia has several features that make it different from other 18xx titles. The most important distinctions are:

     a traffic based system that makes calculating company's revenues easier and faster
     foreign investors (Dragons) trade in certificates in addition to human players
     an absorption mechanism that allows companies to acquire each other


Other interesting points:

     before phase 5, all companies start as minor companies with 40%/20%/20%/20% shares
     converting a company from minor to major requires a direct route from a company base to a historical destination city
     private companies become 2 trains when transferred to a company and also provide extra traffic
     buying trains from bank makes the share price jump up
     the last 2, 3, and 4 train comes with a discount
     withholding money in company doesn't reduce the share price
     tiles can be replaced with another tile of same color, provided the current connections are retained
     bankrupt players are given enough loans to keep them in game, loans are then deducted from final score in the end


				
				
					Dragons
     during stock rounds, the Dragons will also trade
     each stock round begins with a Dragon and Dragons also play between each player
     dragons are interested in company's rank, an indicator based on the sum of trains phase and tokens on board, followed on a special table on the board
     dragons will immediately sell certificates in companies ranked red and will buy certificates ranked green, according to a fairly simple and consistent algorithm.
     players can buy shares from Dragons, but must pay a premium for well-ranked shares
     share prices are adjusted down when shares are sold by Dragons or the company president


				
				
					Traffic system
     when a company places a station marker, it gets to collect traffic chips from the board along the route
     mines also produce traffic chips, but diminish in value as the game proceeds
     each traffic chip is worth $10 in revenue
     revenues are the smaller value of total revenue in traffic chips and train capacity available
     phase 2 trains, for example, have 8 capacity each, so if company has two of those for 16 capacity and 14 traffic chips, it will make $140 in revenue, while adding three chips would increase the revenue to $160 because the capacity hits the roof at that point

Educational game where kids must use correct accentuation and backtick.

At the start of the game, each player receives a pawn and four cards. Each player must roll the dice and move the pawn. There are four kinds of spaces: opponent color, all colors, your color and take a card. If the pawn falls in one of the first two, the player must try to answer correctly a word in one of the opponents cards. The player with most point after 3 rounds is the winner.

From the Wired.Com review of The Goonies 25th Anniversary Edition DVD Set:

".... the set’s true treasure - a special Goonies-themed board game.

The bulk of the box set’s real estate is devoted to this game, and immediately upon cracking open the shrink wrap you are taken by its diminutive size. Still, if The Goonies taught us anything it’s that size doesn’t always matter, and I’m happy to report that this is the case here. Though the board itself is only about half the size of your average game, it’s actually a brilliantly colored fold-up printed on super sturdy laminated stock that appears perfectly capable of standing up to multiple years’ worth of play sessions. The same can be said for the game’s Move Cards which, while not quite as brawny as most CCG cards, are thick enough to get the job done.

Gameplay is fairly simple and properly reflects the spirit of the source materials - players take the role of one of five Goonies (Mikey, Data, Mouth, Chunk or Andy) and use a three-card hand in an attempt to escape One-Eyed Willy’s cave. Players disarm traps to collect Gold Doubloons, and the first to reach the "Escape" square with three such Doubloons wins the game. The process is complicated by a trio of tricky Skull Spaces (only one of which contains the necessary key) that must be passed to reach the exit. This is balanced out by a fun selection of Special Move Cards that allow players to switch places with or steal gold from opponents. While certainly not the most engaging board game experience in movie fandom, it does manage to channel the proper amount of nostalgia and charm in a small but effective package."

Tie the bandana, put on the sunglasses, shrug on the leather jacket, grab your "axe".........and the dice.

Rock 'n Roll is a free print and play dice game in which players compete to become the biggest rock band and make the greatest albums.

Playable solo or multiplayer, players roll dice over an in-game four year period to practice as a band, go out partying to get fans, get famous in the news, hit the studio to release the next big album, tour the country or just earn some cold, hard cash.

Taking on concepts of Yahtzee and push your luck games, Rock 'n Roll gives hard decisions, direct competition and a rockin' theme. Will you be the next big thing or yet another failed garage band?

"Calling all Ninja! Lord Garmadon is on a mission: collect all four Golden Weapons of Spinjitzu and, ultimately, rule the world. Can you stop him?"

NinjaGo is a game made out of LEGO bricks.

The playing pieces are LEGO mini figure on a “spinjitzu” spinning disk. Each figure should be armed with one weapon.

Each player then spins the figures so they collide. You win by knocking the other playing piece over, and the take the defeated warrior’s weapon.

You can also play cards that will enchant your warrior.

There is a base set that can be expanded by adding more ninjas and skeleton warriors.

Seduxion - The game of dice that melts the Ice

The game comes with 8 differnt dice and a scoring pad along with a small rule sheet.

Each of the dice have one face with Lips, Serpents, Apples, fig leaves and Cupids on them. The 6th face contains one letter of the word SEDUXION. 5 of the dice are black the 3 red dice which have the letters S,E,X on it are red. (This combination scores a special bonus)

In turn each player throws all 8 dice and may leave down any, none, or all the dice thrown. Up to 3 rolls are permitted per turn. You get points for more than 3 of the same symbols or have more than 7 differnt faces shown and for making words with at least 3 letters

Example: After 3 rolls you got: 4 Cupids and D, I, E, X. This counts 5 points for the 4 Cupids and 10 points for the word DIE, a total of 15 points. The word SEX gots a special bonus of 30 points.

Every field on the score sheet can be used only once, like in Yatzee. You have to cross out the field on the score sheet. After ten turns one column is finished and the points are calculated together. The games ends here or goes up for 2 other columns on the same score sheet. The winner of a column gets a 50 point bonus.

Should you get SEDUXION at any time this will ends the game and you win the game. In a 3 column game the winner takes a 100 point bonus and all other lose their point on that column.

(from the rules and user summary)

This is a memory-game for the very young.  10 stars cover 5 picture pairs in the sky. The first player picks up two stars and if the pictures underneath are the same the stars are kept.  If not, the stars go back into the sky.  Then the second player picks up two stars, etc.  Who will collect the most stars?  To play a NEW game there is the possibility to change the picture-plates underneath, fitting the colors, around the holes in the corners, to the same colors of the pegs.  There are two plates, printed on both sides, that give four different possibilities.  To add even more playing possibilities, there are 5 papers included for drawing, or gluing pictures or photos.  
To practice before playing memo, you can start with a simple game, where you look for each pair.  One picture is covered with a star, who will find the same picture?

Each player gets a set of acrobats (1 through 5). The objective is to stack the acrobats one on top of the other (from 1 to 5).

Throwing the die; the highest throw starts. Each player throws the die until they get a 1, then a 2 and so on to stack the 5 acrobats. A player who throws a 6 loses a turn. If the stack of acrobats falls, the player will have to start again from 1. (source from the directions on the box)

In the board game of "Aguila Roja", players interpret the characters in the series, during the scenes that occur in the Village. One, two or three players (depending on total number of players) are trying to prevent the Commissioner continue with its plans to capture "Aguila Roja" and kill the King, while a player moves to the Commissioner and is carry out their own. During the game will be happening plot, represent adventure television series. To try resolve these plots, players use cards to move around the board representing the town and its surroundings.


En el juego de Tablero de Águila Roja, los jugadores interpretan a los personajes de la serie, durante las Tramas que ocurren en la Villa. Uno, dos o tres jugadores (dependiendo del número total de jugadores) intentan impedir que el Comisario lleve adelante sus planes de capturar a Águila Roja y matar al Rey, mientras que un jugador mueve al Comisario y trata de llevar a cabo los suyos. Durante la partida se irán sucediéndo Tramas, que representarán aventuras de la serie de televisión. Para tratar de resolver estas tramas, los jugadores usan cartas para moverse por el tablero que representa la Villa y sus alrededores.

A childrens game based on the traditional Norwegian fairytale about the three billy goats who had to cross a bridge where a troll lives.

There is a total of nine billy goats in this game. Three in each color. On your turn you roll a color die and a "normal" die. You move one of the goats of the color the first die shows the number the second die shows. When you come to the bridge you have to draw a troll card to see if the Troll eats the goat.

Each player should collect goats from one color, but the color you collect changes when you reach a "switch color" token.

Compass and Empire is a Print and Play Game themed for the Aether Captains world

Played with 6 dice, five dice showing the Emperor, Lady and Compass faces, and one die known as the ‘Roundabout’, this game is for two to four players. You will also need the provided set of 12 tokens (or coins if the officers are elsewhere).

Play:
At the start of a game the following number of tokens are placed in the center of the playing area, depending on the number of players taking part:

4 players: 3 Emperor tokens, 6 Compass tokens, and 3 Lady tokens
3 players: 2 Emperor tokens, 4 Compass tokens, and 2 Lady tokens
2 players: 1 Emperor tokens, 2 Compass tokens, and 1 Lady token

Choose who goes first.

Players, clockwise in turn, roll the dice once and try to get five-of-a-kind. Players may keep as many of the previous player's dice and roll the remaining ones in their turn.

A player who rolls 5 Compass tokens (regardless if it is the Compass or the Marked Compass) claims one Compass token from the center. A player who rolls 5 Emperor tokens claims one Emperor token from the center. A player who rolls 5 Lady tokens claims one Lady token from the center.

Once a player has made five-of-a-kind and claimed their reward, the next player rolls all the dice to start the next round. If a player is unable to claim their reward from the center because there are none left, they may take one from another player.

If 3 Marked Compass die faces are rolled that player may take the ‘roundabout’ die to use during future turns; rolling it once when taking it to determine its use during the time the player has control of it. The player can only lose that die if another player rolls 3 Marked Compasses and takes it from them.

This die gives the player the following bonuses:

The Engineer - the player is allowed to take a token on a 4 of a kind
(a crafty engineer always makes the best of a situation)

The Mistress - the player allowed to take a 2nd roll of any dice they choose
(one girl here and one girl there)

The Cutpurse - the player can choose one die which will be locked and
cannot be re-rolled by an adjacent player to their left or right as indicated by the die
(the left hand never knows what the right is doing)

The Alchemist - the player may choose any token in center not yet taken
i.e. acts as a 5 wild
(lead turns to gold)

The Spy - The Roundabout die is lost by that player and placed back in the center
(your secrets will gain you nothing)

The first player to hold a Emperor, Lady and two Compass tokens wins the game.

this game is based on the ancient roman game Jactus

From game rules for "Basic" game:

Draw three "public cards" from the Travel deck and place them directly on the map.  Deal each player four Travel cards, and give each player a jet pawn and scoring chip.  Each player chooses one of their cards as their starting location and puts their jet pawn on that city.  Put the card they chose in front of that player to begin a scoring pile, and put their scoring chip on the 1 on the scoring track.

On a player's turn, their jet can make two "hops" as measured using the distance ruler.

Each time a player stops in a city shown on a "public card" or one of their own Travel cards, they take that card and add it to their scoring pile, then move their scoring chip on the scoring track.
				
				
					=========="Advanced" game features additional rules for Event cards, Bonus abilities awarded for completing a set of three cards of the same color, and CoPilot cards awarded when another player visits a Travel card you're holding.

Bonus cards: 
8x Extra jet power (longer hops)
4x Experienced flight crew (extra hop each turn)
4x Extra capacity x4 (hold more cards - also worth a bonus point)
2x Seaplane (can land in water - also worth a bonus point)
4x Collector cards that each double the value of a different color
1x Prestige card worth 3 points

WHAT THEY'LL LEARN: Geography, Strategy, World Facts


     Sequel: Let's Drive

This game was officially released in October 2010 to mark the 32nd anniversary of John Paul's election as pope, although several hundred copies had already been sold.

A dice roll allows a player to travel to many of the 130 countries where the pope traveled where players collect cards with the Pope's messages.

It's feeding time for the chickens, and you've got a lot of hungry mouths to feed in your hen house. So out into the barnyard you go, looking for tasty spiders, worms, beetles, and bits of corn. All you need to do is grab it and bring it back to your henhouse. Unfortunately, there are a lot of other chickens in the yard that are trying to grab the same food! Will you be able to successfully maneuver your chickens to collect the most food and feed your flock?

In Chicken Feed Stampede!, players control a pair of chickens trying to collect food as they run around the barnyard. While doing so, they have to avoid other chickens and the fox, which chases the chickens to the edge of the barnyard, forcing them to the edge to start over.

Each player uses a set of eight action cards to determine how their chickens are moved each turn.

There are four different kinds of food available, and each gives the player who collects it a different ability or score. Player order is managed by placing their turn markers on the "Pecking Order" board. Clever management of your actions to stay at the top of the pecking order is needed to win the game.

The game board is comprised of a grid of various terrain tiles. A chicken's movement ability is based on the terrain of the tile it starts its move from. Using the boulders and gravel paths gets you around faster, but sometimes you need to get into the grass to collect the food you need.

Components
   - Modular Board featuring barnyard terrain
   - 12 chicken tokens (chickeneeples!) in six colors
   - 48 chicken action cards
   - 36 food tokens (spiders, worms, beetles and corn)
   - one fox token
   - 6 chicken turn marker tokens
   - 6 Rooster Crow special power tokens

From Osprey's publicity:

The Dark Age of Britain, from the middle of the 4th century to the end of the 8th, was a time of violence and warfare, when charismatic warlords such as the fabled King Arthur could gather together armies and carve out their own kingdoms. With this new set of wargames rules, players can take on the role of these warlords and command their own armies on the tabletop. Written by the author of the popular Glutter of Ravens rules set, Dux Bellorum is an element-based system, where each base of figures represents 50 fighting men. Each player has a specific number of points with which to construct his force and can choose to a Late Roman, Romano-British, Welsh, Saxon, Pictish, Irish, or Sea Raider army. The game is then played out following a set of simple, fast-paced rules. A completely self-contained gaming system, Dux Bellorum is perfect for gamers who are looking for a way into fighting Dark Age battles without investing a lot of time or money in larger rulesets.

From the playtest introduction:

Dux Bellorum is an Arthurian-era Dark Ages wargame, set in the period from the mid fourth century AD to the end of the eighth century AD. The rules emphasise the influence an army’s commander has on his units, with simple manoeuvre rules and chaotic, swirling close combat. You'll win by inspiring the right troops at the right time, balancing quality versus quantity in your army, and by finding a sprinkling of luck at the right time.

All distances are given in Base Widths, which allows the game to be used with any scale of miniature based in many different ways. An army usually has 6-12 units, and each unit is rated for Aggression (Attacks), Protection (Defence), and Cohesion (Strength) and is trained either as Shieldwall, Warriors, Riders, or Skirmishers (all of which operate differently in the game).

Dux Bellorum armies are selected from following lists: Late Roman, Romano-British, Welsh, Saxon, Pictish, Irish, Land Raider, Sea Raider.

In this fantasy miniatures game players each create an army with the same number of points (with each miniature having a different point value), then take turns moving and attacking until all of the opponent's forces are dead or captured. Players can use special magic and ability cards to provide advantage for their armies.
Unique game mechanic also allows players to launch small plastic missiles with heavy machines (such as ballista or catapult), physically knocking out enemy forces from the battle.

The universe of Fantasy Battles includes various epochs and genres, from fantasy cratures and gladiators to napoleonic wars and cossacks.

Usually each set includes 20 miniatures of characters or creatures, 4-6 warmachines, a deck of magic or ability cards 1 die and techsheets for each unit. Many sets also contain modular structures, such as walls or castle towers.

This fantasy-themed miniatures wargame is set on a hexagonal map with dimensions of 5X7 hexes with special 2 hexes marked as "castles". The goal of this game is to defeat all enemy forces or capture his "castle" hex.
Player may reinforce their armies by purchasing additional units during the game process. Also players may build walls and towers on hex borders to defend their castles.

This game is developed based on ideas from Ð˜Ð¼Ð¿ÐµÑ€Ð°Ñ‚Ð¾Ñ€ and Ð˜Ð¼Ð¿ÐµÑ€Ð°Ñ‚Ð¾Ñ€ 2 games.

Components:
32 warrior miniatures
10 plasic bases with flag and 3 slots for units
12 plastic towers
16 plastic walls
20 gold tokens
1 game map
1 rulebook
1 die

(From the Introduction)

Samurai Wars is a game sited in medieval Japan. Each player represents a "Grand Lord", confronted with the other players for the control of lands and resources (mines, hamlets, castles...) in a combination of stretegy, planification, risk, diplomacy and (mostly) war.

In a game turn, each player must collect his resources in order to pay his army and, or recruit new units. after he can attack at his rivals, or ally with others, or be betrayed for his former allies. In this confussed scenario also are present the peasants, sometimes violent, sometimes powerless..., and the Ninjas, special units who can kill  a "Grand Lord", removing it for the game.

The game units are completd with infantry, bowmen (each represents ten men), and the powerfull samurais.

At the end of the game (20 turns), the winner is the player with most resources controlled. If there is a tie, the game is played one more turn.

Clara's garden is game for 2-6 players. You need 1 set of nestortiles and 1 men for every player.

In Clara's garden is 60 flowers in ten colors. Flowers are in various class (1-6). Goal is pick most valuable flowers for bouquet where every flower will be in different color.

Components
- Nestortiles A-Type (60 tiles) 
- One man for every player.

Setup
Before game players create random map of garden from nestortiles in grid 10x10.

Play
First move: All players in order put his man on tiles with value 1.

Next move: Player pick up tile and move his man diagonally, horizontally or vertically any number of squares. Only one man can be on square. Man can jumps over oposite men.

Game continue with next moves. Because empty fields cannot be crossed, isolated islands of tiles could be removed. Player can pick up more tiles with the color. But into final score will be counted only one most valuable flower for every color.
If player has no move, she picks up last tile and passes next moves.

End of game
Game is finished when one player has completed bouquet (she has tiles of all ten colors) or when all players are out of moves. Score is counted as sum of points of all flowers. If player has more flowers of the same color, only most valuable flower is counted. Player with best score is winner.

In Rule book there are Advanced rules too.

"It's War!! ...but in a nice way."

Good: the Battle is a miniatures based combat skirmish game, in which you take the role of a character or characters and attempt to defeat your opponents by doing good and inflicting bad upon them. The core game, designed by us at Project Good is the game of Good: the Battle. The uniqueness of Good: The Battle is it's ability to use any genre, any miniatures, anywhere, anything else...? Yes there is, but it's all Good...

Unlike the heavily stat-based games that you see everywhere nowadays, Good: the battle turns these statistics  into two basic attributes; Good and bad. Obviously the better you are at things (shooting, close combat, healing, etc.) the longer you will survive in this world, but everyone has a limit of how much Good they can do. Nasty things like damage, curses, etc can only be described as Bad things, but sometimes a bit of bad is exactly what is needed.

There are thousands, probably hundreds of thousands, of character miniature manufacturers out there; and every single one of these can be used in Good: the Battle - regardless of scale, setting, period, race, etc. Good: the Battle uses the actual miniature to give you benefits in the game. For example; a miniature equipped with swords will be better in close combat, than somebody with none. A miniature carrying a rocket launcher will obviously do more damage if it shoots you in the head. Huge dragons will have more hit points, and mice will have less. But this doesn't mean a one-armed dwarf mute who's only weapon is a bag full of dead hamsters won't be able to put up a fight...

Publisher Blurb:

This is no ordinary crossword game...it's unpredictable, it's fast-paced, it's Stir 'em Up! Scoop the letters out of the bowl, but don't get attached - the die may force you to flip them or switch them. And once it's time for everyone to make their own crosswords, don't dawdle - you've got 30 seconds to use more letters than everyone else!

User Summary

Once everyone has their letters, roll the die to stir things up! If the die shows a color, everyone must flip over those color tiles they have. If it lands on "right," they take two tiles from the person  to their right. If it lands on "left," they pass two tiles to the person to their left. Now ask them to
try to form a word with the tiles. The word must have at least three letters (no
one- or two-letter words). The person to announce a word gets the points for that word. Continue playing until all tiles have been used or you run out of room on the board.

A tower is filled with 5 columns of coloured balls. Each player can on their turn take as many balls of the same colour from the bottom of the columns as they want. The winner is the player who has taken the most balls at the end of the game.

Set up the 12 bowling pins and aim to get a strike. This game is fun for everyone and will unleash your competitive side!

Object of the game is to knock all the bowling pins down and score a strike.


Comes with: 1 Bowling Alley, 12 Bowling Pins, 2 side supports 
1 Score Sheets 
1 Instruction Sheet 
2 Bowling Balls 
1 Monkey Bowler

From the front cover: The animals are escaping.  Capture the most to win and become head zoo keeper.

User summary: A roll-and-move game where the players are zookeepers trying to catch all of the animals that have escaped from the zoo.  Based on the roll of a die in the game's unique elephant dice tower, a player will either move his pawn the indicated number of spaces, attempting to land on and capture an animal, or follow the instructions on an event card.  When all of the animals have been captured, the player with the most animals wins.

The Wild, Which-Way-Did-They-Land Game

Spotcha! takes fast eyes and faster hands. Start by tossing the 18 oddball objects and watch how they land. Flip a card and the race is on. Is the lawn mower rightside-up? Is the ghost face down? Look, the wizard hat is on its side! Quick, grab the correct scoring flags before anyone else. Everybody plays on every turn, so it's all-out, mad-cap fun for everyone!

This is a strategic marble stomping game.
Outwit your opponents by stomping their marbles before they stomp yours!
Outmaneuver by leaving their "stomper" trapped with no escape.  OUTSTOMP the competition and you win!
Each player has a "stomper" piece with a marble of a different color attached to the top.  On a player's turn, he or she may stomp any marble (by putting it on top of it, knocking it underneath the board), not in the outside ring.  On the following turn, the player can stomp any adjacent marbles of the same color, or stomp a marble matching the color of his/her "stomper" piece.

Combat Command is a fully playable set of rules that allow you to fight larger skirmish actions of World War II in four hours or less!

Only 18 pages of core rules, all writen in an easy to read style, backed up by over 140 pages of table of organization and equipment data - including airplanes - for all major nationalities!

Scale: one figure equal one man, one weapon, or one vehicle.

This is a game from India published for the purpose of educating children in the teachings of the guru Gnani Purush Shri Ambalal Muljibhai Patel, also known as Dada Bhagwan. It consists of two separate boardgames: "Dada's World", which teaches about how to behave apropriately in given situations and answer questions about the guru's teachings; and "Guess, Who Am I?", which focuses on identifying role models.

Game 1 (Dada's World) - Players roll a die and move along a track which represents their journey through Dada's World, collecting rectangular plastic "coins" with a variety of point values. 
Landing on marked spaces along the track can either add points (Helped Poor Person: 100), subtract points (Killed a cockroach: -150), provide the opportunity to answer questions about Dada's teachings to earn points (Dadai Dhamaka), lose turns, take extra turns, go back to Home, and other similar effects. At certain points on the track, players have the opportunity to pay points to take a shorter route.
The winner is the first player to make a complete circuit of the track and return to the start space with 1500 points or more. Players who complete the track with fewer than 1500 points must go back to an earlier square and try to accumulate more points.

Game 2 (Guess, Who Am I?) - Players roll a die and move along a track collecting pieces of three separate puzzles. Most of the spaces on the board are marked with a statement associated with one of the three "role models" - Parents, Dadashri and Humanity. When landing on a space on the board, players must identify which role model is associated with the statement on that space (example: Space #17 "We should bow down to them every day" is associated with Parents). Correctly identifying the role model allows the player to take the puzzle piece associated with that space. 
Other spaces give the player a free random puzzle piece, allow the player to take a piece from another player, or cause the player to lose a turn. Players who reach the end of the track without winning the game move back to Start and continue to collect puzzle pieces.
To win, a player must collect all 12 pieces of one of the three puzzles. He may then assemble the puzzle to see a picture representing one of the role models, then flip the pieces over to reveal a message.

From the rule booklet:

Hello kids!!!

Time to enter DADA'S WORLD filled with excitement, fun & learn.....

This 2-in-1 Game Pack offer dual knowledge and fun, Get the tracks right from 'Home' to 'Simandhar City' and back 'Home' in Game 1. If you follow the rule you are IN, if you refrain then you commit a SIN.

Also recognize the ROLE MODELS of your life by learning their virtues and identifying them in Game 2. Abount Parents, Dadashri and humanity is what we get to learn.

Wow! So much to do, so much to learn, so little time we want more fun, then grab on this Game Pack 2-in-1.

Publisher Blurb:

Telegruv is the new party game that takes the classic game, Telephone, to the next level.  Draw cards illustrating popular dance moves including: The Twist, The Snake, and Brush Your Shoulders Off.  Perform these moves for your teammates and get ready to laugh as your team tries to keep your dance sequence intact all the way down the line.  The more moves that are completed correctly, the more points your team scores.

The game is ready to play and includes 95 dance cards of varying genre and difficulty, 5 wild cards, a 90-second sand timer, scoring pads, and pencils.

Telegruv is the party game that gets you on your feet!

A variant of Apples to Apples, presented in an apple-shaped box, that includes 'Apple tokens' in three colours: 20 green (1 point), 8 red (2 points), and 2 gold (3 points).

Apples to Apples Family uses two decks of cards: Things and Descriptions. Each turn, the current referee selects a Description and other players try to pick, from the cards in their hands, the Things that best match that Description. The referee then chooses the Thing that appeals most and awards the round to the player who played it. When a player wins a round, they receive a random token.  The first player to five points wins the game.

Contact is a solitaire game, where the player manages and deploys small naval task groups to accomplish random missions that will make up a campaign.

There are two major parts in this game:
- The mission planning/resource management
- The mission execution itself.

First the player determines what forces he will use depending on ships available and mission limitations.
Then, the player allocates weapons (anti ship and anti sub resources) to the platforms he chose.
Finally, the mission itself takes place, where the player deploys the task force in formation (by using a board that mimics a Radar display), and tries to accomplish the mission objectives, that include amongst others:

- Sub hunting
- Convoy Escort
- Sea Superiority
- Convoy raid
- Blockade
- Strategic Strikes

Each mission will have a variable number of turns to be completed and specific objectives, but the Tactical Cards may change all that! Sometimes Intel fails miserably!

The game is composed by:

- 24 Mission Cards - They will define the mission, the objectives, Victory Points, Standing Orders, Rules of Engagement
- 27 Tactical Cards - Will contain random events that will occur throughout the mission.
- 1 Game Board / Radar Display - Where the action takes place!
- 45 Ship Cards - Contain all the relevant information for each unit.
- 45 Ship Counters - To represent the ship card in the board.
- More than 100 counters representing the weapons used by the friendly forces and OPFOR.
- 64 Opposing Force unit counters, that can be either deployed by mission card or drawn randomly by Tactical cards. These include ships, subs and air raids.
- 36 contact counters - Using NTDS symbols, these will represent the location of the enemy forces (or uknown/neutral ones!), until they are positively identified.
- A few system counters
- 1D10 and 1D6 dice will be needed

As a starting point, this game will have one campaign included (Cold War 1985), but others can be easily added later, either by just using the existing components/era settings or by creating new ones.

WEBSITE (under construction): www.pbshots.biz/contact

Pixl is an abstract strategy game based around the balance of elements (fire, earth, water, and spirit). Players lay down blocks of their color and attempt to convert or erase opposing elements -if a Pixl is cornered by two pieces of the opposition a number of points may be awarded depending on the status of the opponent. Each player has the advantage when pursuing their "prey" element and must be eternally weary of their "predator" - who is always hunting them.

The game is structured so as to create an abstracted modern art piece by the conclusion of every game, as the elemental Pixls spiral around each other. While each player has a multitude of Pixls, only one piece in the game (the Port) may move - players must work to master the immobile Pixls and the Port necessary for their survival.

(From the rear of the box:)

The road to the Rhine, and beyond to Berlin, seemed wide open in the early fall of 1944. The German armies in France had ceased being organized formations and were streaming back to the Reich in willy nilly fashion, hotly pursued by the Western Allied armies as they dashed through Paris and to the borders of Germany. The First US Army (with the Ninth later on), hit the Westwall on September 12th and was destined to slog through the mud and rain for months against the fortifications and surprisingly resilient German reserves hurriedly thrown against them in a desperate bid to keep the American army off as much German soil as possible. Additionally, lack of supply served to further restrain the American advance. Would the war be over by Christmas, or would the Germans pull off a second “Miracle of the Marne” and hold long enough to launch a counteroffensive in the west ?


(from Decision Games website:)

HURTGEN: Hell’s Forest is a grand-tactical simulation of that enormous campaign. The 2,240 counters in the game represent almost every formation, at company and battalion levels, which fought in the battle, including US, German, British, and even Belgian units. Infantry, armor, anti-tank, reconnaissance, engineer, assault gun, howitzer, rocket, parachute, ranger, glider, and headquarters units are all fully represented in the counter-mix. The two map sections are an accurate representation of the battle area and were compiled from 1944 German staff maps and 1943-1944 US Army map sources. The area portrayed shows all primary and secondary roads, trails and other types of terrain in relation to their suitability for armor and infantry, along with all the villages, towns and  cities that proved to be the bastions of the German defense, as well as every creek and river that couldn't be crossed by wheeled vehicles without a bridge.

THERE are three main scenarios representing each of the offensive periods of September, October and November. A smaller learning scenario depicts the US 28th Infantry Division’s ordeal as it attempted to drive on the Roer River dams through the forest of the area. Players may also play continuously from September to the first week of December (almost 300 game turns!). The big challenge for the allied player is to see if he can reach the Rhine River months ahead of the actual date, and shorten the war considerably. Extensive supply, weather and air power rules are included.

THIS latest edition of the Grand Operational Simulation Series (which began with Wacht am Rhein) presents further refinements to the combat, artillery and supply subsystems in order to better depict tactical and operational warfare at this scale. For example, rules for “Lull” periods have been added in order to allow players to speed up game play during periods of relative inactivity. These Lulls compress game play from three turns per day to one, allowing players to cover longer intervals of historic time. Other additions feature level-two entrenchments that allow the German player to create fortified bastions in German towns and cities that can better withstand Allied barrages and ground assaults, along with rules that represent the logistical nightmare faced by the Americans during much of the battle.

THE orders of battle have been extensively researched in order to provide an accurate and functional depiction of the armies of both sides. The incredibly hodge podge nature of the resurrecting German army is shown through the depiction of the various rear area units and replacement army battalions that appear almost randomly throughout the game.

GAME SCALE
• Map: 1 mile per hex
• Time: 3 Game Turns per day
• Units: Infantry and Artillery are battalions. Armor is depicted at the company level.
• Each strength step is equal to a company.

GAME COMPONENTS
•   2 22x34” Four Color Map sheets
•   2,240 Die-Cut Playing Pieces (ACTUALLY 1,960!)
•   One Rule Booklet
•   One Scenario Booklet
•   One Full color Examples of Play Booklet
•   Player Aid Charts
•   Two 10-sided Dice
•   Storage Bags
•   11x17x2 inch box

This is a religious-themed trivia game. The trivia questions are religious in nature and are asked and answered in a mechanism simulating a simple baseball game.
 Contents include: game board, question & answer booklet, eight markers (pegs), 6 sided die. Instructions are included in the Q&A booklet

Wizards and sorcerers from all around the world get together in a contest of potions.  They open the old Grimoires and start selecting potions and ingredients.  The rules are strict and only the best will prevail.

Potions Festival is card game were the players collect ingredients to make potions.  The ingredients are at the center of table and the potions are hidden.  The ingredient cards are placed or moved to match the sequence of the potion..  They must lie in single path.  You can choose any needed ingredients as long as
they are connected in a single path. You cannot backtrack at the
path or pass twice by a card.

There are four kinds of ingredients and three types of magic.  At the end of the game additional points are earned by who have most from each type of magic and also for those who collected all three types.

Includes:

•Red Deck (33 cards)
•Blue Deck (40 cards)
•Game Rules Document

Sicic is a game for two. Each player guides a group of Astronomers, aiming at copying the opponent’s Constellation. Sicic is played on two 8 × 8 squared boards, named the Earth and the Sky. Each player has 4 pieces that move on the Earth (the Astronomers) and 4 pieces to be placed in the Sky (the Stars). The Stars are the player’s Constellation. There are three phases: the Afternoon, the Evening and the Night. One of the player will be the first to move in every phase of the game.

In the Afternoon, players alternate placing one Astronomer at a time on the Earth, on an empty square. In the Evening, players alternate placing one Star at a time in the Sky, on an empty square. In the Night, each player must move one of his Astronomer every turn. The Astronomer can move in a direct line in every direction, any number of unoccupied squares. He must land in an unoccupied square. The Astronomer may choose not to move, in order to “pinch” one of the opponent’s Astronomers set in a neighbouring square. The result of a pinch is that the pinched Astronomer must move in the next turn. Moreover, it is forbidden to the opponent, in the second next turn, to pinch an Astronomer that occupies the abandoned square.

The winner is the first player who manages to place his Astronomers in the same way as the opponent’s Stars. Translations, reflections and rotations are allowed. Also, a player can win by pinching an Astronomer that is not able to move.

Sicic is latin for “stellae inerrantes caeli imitatio consequi”.

Online Play: Super Duper Games

This game is played on a 10x10 square board.

On your turn, place a friendly stone on an empty cell.

You win by connecting the two opposite board edges of your color with either a chain of orthogonally connected stones of your color or a chain of diagonally connected stones of your color. There must not be both diagonal and orthogonal connections in a winning group.

“Punic Island” is the third volume in the Campaign Commander series and simulates the campaign for Sicily and North Africa during the First Punic War. The system takes away from Second World War and goes to Ancients. In 264 Roma was summoned to Messina by Mamertines mercenaries to help in their quarrel with Cartage, the main power in Sicily. Carthaginians count on Hiero the Tirant of Syracuse to help defeating the Mamertines. Here begins the First Punic War.
Romans and Carthaginians fought for 22 year over Sicily and in North Africa. Rome emerged victorious and Cartage was obliged to quit his long standing presence in Sicily.
The land campaign was a long string of Roman victories as city after city was subdued and every Carthaginian army was defeated in battle. Syracuse was forced to make an alliance with Rome and Cartage was left with only a few fortresses in the island.
Anyway the war was won and lost in the sea. The war saw the emergence of Rome as a sea-power and a long string of naval victories allow Roman troops to menace even Cartage proper. Only to be saved by Xantipus and his mercenary army at the Bagradas Plains battle. Naval warfare played a prominent role in this war and will give Carthage Senate his las blow. Carthage tried to spend the Roman effort during the whole war. His strategy was of attrition and was unsuccessful; Rome never gave up a prize.
The game is developed in an operational scale – area-based map. It is designed for two players with one running the ROMAN forces and the other the CARTHAGINIAN forces -including Syracuse. The game lasts approximately 3-4 hours and uses a two sided system to handle the mechanics of play: cards and counters. The players will have to use their troops and their resources to obtain victory points while eliminating enemy forces and occupying cities in the map. It is not a card driven game as the cards are used to bring about events that influence battles, secure reinforcements, and provide resources with which to carry on the fight.
The ROMAN player will be on the offensive during the whole game as he has to conquer the whole island to get victory. CARTHAGINIAN player focuses on spoiling Roman campaigns and plans with ambushes, sallies and bad weather cards. Also he has to recruit an army as he doesn´t has any at the beginning of the game.
The ROMAN player must plan his offensives carefully as he will need a new army and resources for each one. Also he will need to build a fleet his doesn´t have at the start of the war. The sea contest will be evenly match and you better take into account bad weather as it sinks more ships than enemy action.
Siege warfare takes a prominent role in this game as every city in the game map is a walled on with his own intrinsic garrison.
Like all the games of this Series, the rules are simple and straight forward. Our objective was to create games that are very interactive, and offer players a pleasant creative experience. We aim for solid games for players who do not have the time or the space to leave a game setup and in place over a long period of play.

Components:
- 1 80x60 cm map of Sicily and North Africa.
- two ten-sided dice
- 176 unit counters
- 1 Rules Book for the Series “Campaign Commander” and Exclusive Rules of “Punic Island”; historical and designer notes.
- 70 cards (divided in two decks, plus help cards)
- 3 plastic bags.

With this game players will try to look into their future.

The game is placed in the center of the table. Each turn the player swings the pendulum above the board. The place where the pendulum lands decides wether a player has to use the 'moodring'. 
The 'moodring' at the end of the pendulum changes its color when it's put on the player's finger. The player takes the corresponding assignment card and has to fulfill the assignment.
The game also contents 'magic stones'. These stones are needed with some of the assignments.

The object of the game is to learn more about yourself, your friends or about your future.

User Description:

Fruity Bugs is a game from the Tesco Junior range for 2 to 4 players aged 4 and up.  The game includes one clockwork, strawberry board, 4 worm cards (1 blue, 1 green, 1 red and 1 yellow) and 20 green worms with coloured tail ends, 5 worms in each of the 4 colours.

You set the game up by randomly placing the worms in the holes in the strawberry and then each player selects a colour.  The aim of the game is to be the first player to get all 5 worms in your colour.  There is a lever at the top of the board, pull it and release to make the worms start wiggling (you'll have to repeat this frequently throughout the game as it only lasts for 10 seconds or so).

Once started players take it in turns, beginning with the youngest player, to grab a worm from the strawberry.  If it matches their card they keep it, if not they put it back and then the next player goes.  You keep going around until one player gets all of their 5 worms.

This is a very simple kids memory game with a dexterity element as you try and grab the wiggling worms as they move up and down in the board.

This game is played on a 8x8 square board.
Setup:Initially,each player drops two friendly stones on empty cells.
On each turn,each player expands a connected line of one or more friendly stones.
A line of stones expands by doubling its size in one of the two directions it is defined.
When the board is full,wins the player with more friendly stones.

Discover an amazing world of warrior heroes, towering castles and brilliant, all-action battles to play with your friends.

The gameplay is fantastic fun - including crossbows and catapults that really do work. Castle towers with "explosive" special effects that send your enemies flying and some serious spells to cast upon anyone who dares oppose you.

So set out your castle keeps, tents, towers, crossbows and catapults. Build your rampart defenses and place your warriors in strategic positions. Then take it in turns to fire your projectiles - including the deadly fireballs, boiling oil and boulder bursts. Destroy your enemies defenses and weapons of awesome power before the destroy you.

Good luck and may glorious victory be yours!

This is a set of tactical rules for gun-fights and shoot-outs in the setting of the American Wild West.  The gun-fights take place as a table top miniature game which uses 25mm scale miniatures.  The rules cover everything that is needed to play including character design and stats, scenario creation and even rules for campaign games.  There are floor plans included in the rule book, or the game master can create their own.

The battles can take place outdoors for example in the middle of a western town, or even indoors, such as in saloons, banks, etc.  Once each player has his character or gang of characters, then each player takes turns moving and firing at each other until there is one player (or team) remaining.

Idea of the game: The zoo is in a muddle: all the animals may get out of their enclosures and are drawn today. The colour combination of the dice decides which is the next animal to be drawn to complete one's row. Who can draw the longest row of animals. A drawing and dice game. Contains rules for older players.

From the back of the box:
"Deal up murder and mayhem with the simple murder mystery game that's played with cards. 'Dealing with Murder' requires no fancy parties or petit'fours, just round up your favorite rival detectives and deal them into a baffling murder mystery which unfolds as the cards are dealt.
  
Who will be the first detective to identify the killer?  Will you cooperate with your fellow sleuths...or withhold some evidence...to give yourself an edge in solving the crime?

A singular murder mystery experience for 2 to 6 amateur detectives aged 12 to adult.

Contents include a unique 55 card deck of clues, tips and evidence; crime scene photos and suspect profiles; game instructions and a sealed crime solution.

Object of the Game:
To be the first detective to solve the crime by correctly stating 1)Who the murderer is 2) The motive, and 3) How it was accomplished.

Similar to/same series as:
Dealing With Murder: Fatal Error

Rechenakrobat (Calculation Acrobat)

Rechenakrobat is game consisting out of five dice only. It is a mathematical game in which the player tries to make a correct calculation with the thrown values of the dice.

With the eyes of the 5 coloured dice the number thrown with the 2 black dice should be calculated through addition, subtraction, multiplication or division.

"Lebst Du nur, oder spielst Du schon?" / "Still living, or already playing"?
Mini version of 'Billiard' or 'Pool'. There are many different versions of this game of skill, but ultimately you have to use a cue stick with which to hit balls into the table's six pockets.

From the publisher:
Easiest party game for couples. This game is a good way to learn about your friends and family, to find people who think like you.
The couple that wins the game is the one who "clicks" more and gets to the finish first. Only thing you need to do in this game is to pick words from word pairs and then check, if your partner thinks the same. Is it blond or dark - your choice?

Autokrator (a.k.a. emperor) is a medieval Euro/wargame about the wars from the 7th to the 11th century between Christians and Muslims. In Autokrator, you control one of the major kingdoms/Caliphates of the Medieval Age – the Franks/Holy Roman Empire, the Moors, the Saracens, the East Roman Empire (Byzantines) – with each kingdom striving to protect and expand its domination.

The players use four characters each round – the King, the General, the Admiral, and the Garrison – with each character having special abilities. What's more, each player has his own "battlecard" deck of armies and must divide them strategically between his characters at the begining of every new turn. The original combat system is based on the choices that the players have, and the battle is fought between five battlefields: Plain, Hill, Forest, City and Ambush. The game lasts five rounds, and players win or lose victory points based on the winning battles and the territories that they control.

Make your choices wisely, and take a chance on becoming the next Autokrator!

Collector is played on a 6x6 square board.
On each turn,a player must drop a friendly stone and a neutral stone,both on adjacent empty cells.
When all cells are occupied,wins the player with the largest group.
Collector is presented at 100 Strategic Games for Pen and Paper by Walter Joris.

Kill Ball is a science fiction tabletop sports game for two players created by Gil Nicoll and Adam Watts. It uses tokens or minis on a gridded board to represent a match between two teams of human clones in a gritty arena environment.

Gameplay is an ultra-violent hybrid of handball and hockey. Clones are extremely disposable, and inflicting serious injuries and death upon the opponent’s team is a major part of the game’s strategy. A decapitation will add an additional ball to the arena which can also be used as weapon.

In leagues and tournaments, each player generates a unique team that carries on from game to game. Clones who suffer injuries or death in the arena will have temporary to permanent reductions to their stats, but are easily replaceable between matches. The ones that survive are awarded experience which can be used to improve attributes and purchase additional abilities.

Grid Snakes is a quick-playing game with some real-world dexterity elements for two, four, or six players (with variant rules for three, five, and seven to twelve players). You’re a digital snake, trapped in an arena with several other snakes. As you move, you leave body segments behind you. Your goal is to eliminate your opponents by forcing your opponents to crash into the edge of the board or and section of any other player.

Play is simultaneous (so there's no down time) and proceeds through the following phases: plan, challenge, resolve.  During planning, you have a just a handful seconds to pick a direction and a speed for your snake. When all instructions are revealed, any player may spend a token to challenge another player.  If you're challenged, you have to flick a token onto a chart; where it lands dictates your speed for the turn.  During resolution, you move the snakes, add body segments, and check for collisions.

Grid Snakes uses a large and a small custom board, several small custom decks of cards (eight cards each), some nickels or quarters, and a lot of colored glass beads (or other small tokens). The rules and cards are available at: http://www.invisible-city.com/file_download/165/

Grid Snakes has fairly simple rules, but requires quick decision making and planning. Grid Snakes is appropriate for ages 12 and up. If you eliminate the timer, you could probably play this game with slightly younger children. If you allow multiple attempts on reflex challenges, you could go even younger. A four-player game takes 30 minutes or fewer to play. A six-player game takes 40 minutes or fewer.

This tile laying games pits two players against each other, trying to build point-winning diamonds and rubies, whilst blocking your opponent's efforts.

There are bonus tiles that let you make double moves or swap out tiles from the game.

The tiles are rhombus-shaped, with 30 per player, and each player takes their turn adding a tile to the table, one at a time, until the winner is declared.
